title: Bernie and Hillary are among the class of 2017 commencement speakers
text:

‚ÄúNow all I have to do is take a deep breath, squint at the red banners and convince myself that I am at the world‚Äôs largest Gryffindor reunion,‚Äù said J.K. Rowling , as she addressed the crowd at Harvard‚Äôs 2008 commencement. 
Each year, colleges and universities across the country invite notable figures like Rowling to attend their graduation ceremonies and address their graduating classes. It seems like everyone from Madeleine Albright to Kermit the Frog has delivered a commencement address. 
With graduation only months away, schools have already begun to announce their commencement speakers for the Class of 2017. Here are some notable confirmed graduation speakers so far. Wellesley College: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton 
In May, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton will return to her alma mater to deliver the school‚Äôs 2017 commencement address . Hillary Rodham Clinton '69 is a true champion of women & girls. We're honored she will address our 2017 graduates. https://t.co/ES98yeElN6 
‚Äî Paula Johnson, MD (@DrPaulaJohnson) February 2, 2017 
The 2016 Democratic nominee was, famously, Wellesley‚Äôs first student speaker when she graduated in 1969 . Although Clinton had prepared a speech for the event, she abandoned it to critique Senator Edward Brooke‚Äôs earlier remarks, in which he asserted ‚Äúcoercive protest‚Äù was ‚Äúwrong.‚Äù 
Clinton‚Äôs speech earned her widespread recognition and, in many ways, launched her career as a public figure. Brooklyn College: Senator Bernie Sanders U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) will be the 2017 Brooklyn College commencement speaker. (Photo: Justin Sullivan, Getty Images) 
Senator Bernie Sanders will journey to Brooklyn College this spring to address the Class of 2017. Just announced: @SenSanders will be our 2017 commencement speaker at @barclayscenter in May! #BCfamily #FeeltheBern pic.twitter.com/NWAm8n2lGq 
‚Äî Brooklyn College (@BklynCollege411) February 2, 2017 
Sanders was not only born in Brooklyn, but also lived in the NYC borough until age 19 . He attended Brooklyn College, before transferring to the University of Chicago. The longest serving independent member of Congress in U.S. history is known for his popularity among America‚Äôs youth. 
‚ÄúWe are honored to be able to welcome Bernie home this spring to this great college, and to have him send off the Class of 2017,‚Äù said Michelle J. Anderson, the president of Brooklyn College. Related: Michelle Obama in final commencement address as first lady: Embrace diversity Massachusetts Institute of Technology: Apple CEO Tim Cook 
The CEO of Apple, Inc. will speak at MIT‚Äôs 2017 commencement ceremony. Cook succeeded Apple co-founder Steve Jobs in 2011 and is listed as #32 on Forbes ‚Äò Most Powerful People 2016 . 
When asked to remark on his upcoming commencement speech at MIT, Cook told The Tech , ‚ÄúThe student body at MIT has always appreciated that technology should play a larger role in society, that it‚Äôs not just about technology. It‚Äôs about the intersection of technology and liberal arts that‚Äôs really good for our country. That parallel endeared me to MIT.‚Äù University of Pennsylvania: Senator Cory Booker 
UPenn will welcome New Jersey Senator Cory Booker to campus on May 15, when he will deliver his commencement address to the Class of 2017. In a statement , President Amy Gutmann referred to Booker as ‚Äúa passionate advocate and defender of our nation‚Äôs most important democratic ideals.‚Äù In @Penn 's statement on @CoryBooker as Commencement speaker, specific mention of his record on immigration reform. https://t.co/keAj4xrjRi pic.twitter.com/dWi0bXx93H 
‚Äî Caroline Simon (@carolinesimon66) January 31, 2017 University of Wisconsin-Madison: TV writer Steven Levitan 
Nine-time Emmy award-winning writer Steven Levitan will speak at the University of Wisconsin-Madison‚Äôs 2017 spring commencement. The 1984 UW-Madison graduate and television veteran is the co-creator of ABC‚Äôs hit-comedy ‚ÄúModern Family.‚Äù We wouldn't have @ModernFam without @SteveLevitan , and we're proud to have him as our Spring 2017 #uwgrad speaker. üéì https://t.co/axEZpK89J6 pic.twitter.com/Dp5wmI5ebM 
Reflecting on Levitan‚Äôs upcoming speech a statement, Chancellor Rebecca Blank added , ‚ÄúI suspect this year‚Äôs graduates will get a few laughs along with some good advice.‚Äù 
Contributing: Paul Frangipane, Brooklyn College, member of the USA TODAY College contributor network. Lauren Padilla is a student at Johns Hopkins University and a USA TODAY College digital producer.
